Taiga (/ˈtaɪɡə/; Russian: тайга́; [tɐjˈɡa]; from Turkic) also known as boreal [MASK] or snow forest, is a biome characterized by coniferous forests consisting mostly of pines, spruces and larches.
Taiga (/ˈtaɪɡə/; Russian: тайга́; [tɐjˈɡa]; from Turkic) also known as boreal forest or snow [MASK], is a biome characterized by coniferous forests consisting mostly of pines, spruces and larches.

For example, the taiga of North America mostly consists of spruces; Scandinavian and Finnish taiga consists of a mix of spruce, pines and birch; Russian taiga has spruces, pines and larches depending on the region, while the Eastern Siberian taiga is a vast larch [MASK].

A different use of the term taiga is often encountered in the English language, with "boreal [MASK]" used in the United States and Canada to refer to only the more southerly part of the biome, while "taiga" is used to describe the more barren areas of the northernmost part of the biome approaching the tree line and the tundra biome.
Although at high elevations taiga grades into alpine tundra through Krummholz, it is not an alpine biome only like subalpine [MASK], and much of taiga is lowlands.

In association football, the [MASK] is the person responsible for enforcing the Laws of the Game during the course of a match.
